During the lecture, we encoded the three boolean members single, rich, and female using one byte  b using the following rules as illustrated by this figure:

bit 7 bit 6 bit 5 bit 4 bit 3 bit 2 bit 1 bit 0

With this routing algorithm, the node forwards each (unseen) packet on all outgoing interfaces, except the one the packet came in from.

Fill in the blanks.

Consider this network of routers A, B, C, and D that are using Distance Vector Routing. Assume that all routers are turned on at the exactly same time 0. handler.question_text:
Matching.

Match each socket function call to the sequence it will appear on a Java TCP server. The first/earliest call is assigned the number 1. The earlier is a function call, the smaller is its assigned number. The statements must be compatible (i.e., use appropriate variables from earlier valid statements).

- If a call is NOT absolutely necessary, assign it the number 99. 

- If a call is NOT applicable to a TCP server socket, assign it the number 77.

- If two calls can be interchanged, assign them the same number.

Matching.

- If a call is NOT absolutely necessary, assign it the number 99. 

- If a call is NOT applicable to a TCP server socket, assign it the number 77.

- If two calls can be interchanged, assign them the same number.

drop all damaged frames even if only one bit is damaged in each.
handler.answer: drop all damaged frames even if only one bit is damaged in each.

Select the best answer from each dropdown menu

The objective is to trace the first FIVE frames that will appear on Segments 1 and 2 as a result of the actions of ONE user. If there are less frames or some field does not apply, fill the cells with N/A. 

Read carefully the scenario below.

Consider this network (Due to space limitations, the beginning 128.194. is omitted for all IP addresses on the figure and the IP addresses tables):

The IP and MAC addresses are on this table:

Host Names A B C DNS Router Segment 3 Router Segment 1
IP Addresses 14.173/24 14.187/24 14.2/24 27.10/24 27.254/24 14.254/24
MAC Addresses Ea Eb Ec Ed EX3 EX1

 

The routing tables on Hosts A, B, and C are identical:

Destination Netmask Router (IP address)
0.0.0.0 255.255.255.0 128.194.14.254

The routing table for the DNS host is:

Destination Netmask Router (IP address)
0.0.0.0 255.255.255.0 128.194.27.254

We assume that

1) all hosts on this network are running correctly and that Telnet accepts connections on each host.

2) initially, the ARP cache of each machine is already populated with entries for all the other machines on the same subnet.

3) Bridge cache is initially empty.

3) the user types on Host A the command "Telnet C". 

Seg. MAC D. MAC S. Type IP D. IP S. Prot # Port D. Port S. Flags
_________

Detect up to one corrupted bit using even parity
Detect and correct up to one corrupted bit
Detect and correct up to two corrupted bit

Detect up to one corrupted bit using even parity

Detect and correct up to two corrupted bit

handler.question_text:
Select the best answer.

This question explores the time to send and acknowledge a frame with n bits when using retransmission or forward error correction on a noisy (error-prone) channel.

When using retransmission, the frame is padded with m check bits while with forward error correction, the frame is padded with m' bits with m ′ > m . 

When using forward error correction, the time between when a sender receives a positive acknowledgement and when it sends the frame is  about _______________ assuming a propagation time T p  and a bit rate b e r . We assume that forward error correction always succeeds to correct.
options: T p + ( n + m ′ ) b r T p + ( n + m ′ ) b r T p + ( n + m ′ ) b r
2. T p + ( n + m ′ ) b r 2. T p + ( n + m ′ ) b r 2. T p + ( n + m ′ ) b r
2. T p + m ′ b r 2. T p + m ′ b r 2. T p + m ′ b r
handler.answer: 2. T p + ( n + m ′ ) b r 2. T p + ( n + m ′ ) b r 2. T p + ( n + m ′ ) b r

You should complete the readings and view the lecture (Video 4 and all slides in the presentation, all of the videos, and all of the readings assigned in this module) before attempting this review.

Resources

  • Module 14 Video 4 Wrap-Up (04:13)
  • Module 14, All Slides

handler.question_text:
Numerical answer.

This question explores sharing a channel with capacity of 100 Mbps  using a static or a dynamic allocation.  The static allocation creates channels with equal capacity of 20 Mbps.

We assume:

–The interarrival time of the packets generated by the stations is exponentially distributed (i.e., arrivals form a  Poisson process)

The size of the packets is exponentially distributed (i.e., the transmission time of a packet is exponentially distributed).

 

With dynamic allocation, the average packet delivery is ____________  times smaller than with static allocation.

handler.question_text:
Numerical  answer.

In order to evaluate the Pure Aloha protocol, we defined  N as the number of new frames  (on all stations) to be transmitted per "frame time".  "frame time" was defined as the time to transmit one frame (transmission time, as we neglect the propagation time). We also defined  G as the number of generated frames  (on all stations) to be transmitted per "frame time".

Assume that the generated traffic is Poisson ( G = 0.25 ) and that we are using the transmission time T r as unit. The probability that 0 frame are generated during 0.5 unit time is ______________. 

 

Help:  P [ k , t ] = ( λ . t ) k e − λ . t k !

handler.question_text:
Numerical answer.

This question uses the Conservation Law that states that if a scheduler is work-conserving (i.e., the resource is not used only if the queue is empty),

∑ λ i x i q i = c o n s t a n t

where  λ i is the mean arrival rate,  x i is the mean service time, and  q i is mean queueing time.

Consider two flows with arrival rate 10  Mbps and 25 Mbps that share an OC3 150 Mbps output link.  With FCFS, both mean queueing delays are 0.5 ms. With a new packet scheduling policy,  A's mean delay is reduced to 0.2 ms. The B's new mean queueing delay is _______ ms. Packet size is  P s .

handler.question_text:
Check all that apply.

Consider a switch for which the bit rate on each output is greater or equal to  the sum of bit rates on all inputs. The switch handles bursty data traffic. We assume that the switch processing time is considerable.
options: such a switch must have output queues
such a switch must have input queues
answer: such a switch must have input queues

This question is about the Conservation Law that states that if a scheduler is work-conserving (i.e., the resource is not used only if the queue is empty),

∑ λ i x i q i = c o n s t a n t

where  λ i is the mean arrival rate,  x i is the mean service time, and  q i is mean queueing time.

Consider two flows with arrival rate 10  Mbps and 25 Mbps that share an OC3 150 Mbps output link.  With FCFS, both mean queueing delays are 0.5 ms. With a new packet scheduling policy,  A's mean delay is increased to 1.7 ms. The B's new mean queueing delay CANNOT be _______.

handler.question_text:
Numerical answer.

Consider a switch that contains  (among other packets) segments* with sequence numbers 15, 25, 35, 45, 55, 65, and 75 of a given TCP connection. Segments #75 and #15  are at the tail and front of the queue, respectively. Segment #5 was received correctly by the receiver.

If the switch drops a packet using the drop tail buffer management policy and the remaining segments inside the switch are received in order, these segments may generate up to _________________  duplicate acknowledgement(s). Answer 99 is the number is undetermined based on the provided information.

 

*The 10 byte segment is encapsulated in a packet.
